stories.text:
While looking for an NPM package to handle keyboard input, I ran across the package `@fluentui/keyboard-key` from Microsoft's fluentui repository - but when going to install it, I noticed that their README asked me to install a slightly different package: `keyboard-key` – without the namespace.

Curious, I went to take a look at the package that Microsoft's README recommended I install, and found out that said package had an identical README, but a different author, and a different LICENSE:

    Copyright (c) 2018 Levi Thomason
As opposed to Microsoft's copy, which reads:

    Copyright (c) Microsoft Corporation
If you take a look at the source of these two packages, they're obviously related. The exported API is the same, the comments are mostly the same, and if you take a look at the commit history of fluentui, it turns out that Microsoft was originally using Levi Thomason's keyboard-key package. The commit where they forked it is here:

https://github.com/microsoft/fluentui/pull/13264/files

My question: is this kind of blatant copying and then reassigning of copyrights by megacorps legal? And if not, is there anything we can do it?
stories.title: Ask HN: Microsoft copied this MIT-licensed package. Is it legal?
